description: Enterprise techniques used by APT41, ATT&CK group G0096 v1.0
name: APT41 (G0096)

techniques.comment: [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used the net share command as part of network reconnaissance.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used the netstat command as part of network reconnaissance. The group has also used a malware variant, HIGHNOON, to enumerate active RDP sessions.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) leveraged the follow exploits in their operations: CVE-2012-0158, CVE-2015-1641, CVE-2017-0199, CVE-2017-11882, and CVE-2019-3396.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used legitimate executables to perform DLL side-loading of their malware.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) deleted files from the system.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used compiled HTML (.chm) files for targeting.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used the Steam community page as a fallback mechanism for C2.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) malware TIDYELF loaded the main WINTERLOVE component by injecting it into the iexplore.exe process.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used DNS for C2 communications.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) collected MAC addresses from victim machines.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) created user accounts and adds them to the User and Admin groups.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used a compromised account to create a scheduled task on a system.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) modified legitimate Windows services to install malware backdoors.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) attempted to remove evidence of some of its activity by deleting Bash histories.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used cmd.exe /c to execute commands on remote machines.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used a ransomware called Encryptor RaaS to encrypt files on the targeted systems and provide a ransom note to the user.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used legitimate websites for C2 through dead drop resolvers (DDR), including GitHub, Pastebin, and Microsoft TechNet.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) deployed a Monero cryptocurrency mining tool in a victim’s environment.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) created a RAR archive of targeted files for exfiltration.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used a malware variant called GOODLUCK to modify the registry in order to steal credentials.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) attempted to remove evidence of some of its activity by clearing Windows security and system events.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) created and modified startup files for persistence.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used the WMIEXEC utility to execute whoami commands on remote machines.

[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used WMI in several ways, including for execution of commands via WMIEXEC as well as for persistence via [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194).
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used compromised credentials to log on to other systems.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used a keylogger called GEARSHIFT on a target system.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) gained access to production environments where they could inject malicious code into legitimate, signed files and widely distribute them to end users.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used DGA to change their C2 servers monthly.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used a tool called CLASSFON to covertly proxy network communications.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) compromised an online billing/payment service using VPN access between a third-party service provider and the targeted payment service.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) sent spearphishing emails with attachments such as compiled HTML (.chm) files to initially compromise their victims.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) attempted to masquerade their files as popular anti-virus software.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) leveraged PowerShell to deploy malware families in victims’ environments.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) leveraged sticky keys to establish persistence.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used the Windows Credential Editor to dump password hashes from memory and authenticate other user accounts.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used RDP for lateral movement.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used a malware variant called WIDETONE to conduct port scans on the specified subnets.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) performed password brute-force attacks on the local admin account.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) deployed Master Boot Record bootkits on Windows systems to hide their malware and maintain persistence on victim systems.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) deployed rootkits on Linux systems.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) leveraged code-signing certificates to sign malware when targeting both gaming and non-gaming organizations.
